Borneo (1945) |commander1= |notable_commanders=[[Gordon Steege]] (1943) |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label=Callsign |equipment= |equipment_label=Aircraft }} '''No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit''' is a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) [[radar]] surveillance and air defence unit. Located at [[RAAF Base Darwin]], Northern Territory, it is controlled by [[No. 41 Wing RAAF|No. 41 Wing]], under [[Surveillance and Response Group RAAF|Surveillance and Response Group]].{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Surveillance-and-Response-Group?RAAF-Em/lTbOjboHa5jhkS926exeF05x7rnKL|title=Surveillance and Response Group|publisher=[[Royal Australian Air Force]]|accessdate=4 June 2013}} Its role is to "prepare for, conduct and sustain effective deployable Air Surveillance and Air Battle Management in the Unit's designated area of responsibility".{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Surveillance-and-Response-Group/No.-41-Wing/No.-114-Mobile-Control-and-Reporting-Unit/?RAAF-+2dXErwePPuwhYHpunMpfKIZxfNVdxcd|title=No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit |publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=4 June 2013}} The unit was formed during World War II, and deployed in the [[South West Pacific Theatre of World War II|South West Pacific]]. Since the war it has seen service in the [[Malayan Emergency]], the [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|''Konfrontasi'']] between Indonesia and Malaysia in the mid-1960s, and the [[Operation Slipper|War in Afghanistan]]. ==History== ===World War II=== [[File:No. 114 MFCU (AWM P02874.186).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.24|RAAF personnel examine a sign at the entrance to No. 114 Fighter Control Unit headquarters on Los Negros, in the Admiralty Islands, April 1944|alt=Two men in light-coloured uniforms with a sign reading "Perth 5290, Adelaide 3507, Young & Jacksons Pub Melbourne 2990, Sydney 2472, Brisbane 1955, Townsville 1237"]] No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit was formed as No. 14 (Mobile) Fighter Sector Headquarters at [[Camden, New South Wales|Camden]], New South Wales, on 23 May 1943, under the command of Wing Commander [[Gordon Steege]]. The following month it deployed to [[Goodenough Island]] in [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea]] as part of [[No. 71 Wing RAAF|No. 71 (Fighter) Wing]], and became operational on 27 June.RAAF Historical Section, ''Radar Units'', pp. 131–137 It controlled two [[radar]] stations, No. 401 of the [[Signal Corps (United States Army)|US Army Signal Corps]] and No. 305 of the RAAF.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Surveillance-and-Response-Group/No.-41-Wing/No.-114-Mobile-Control-and-Reporting-Unit/?RAAF-+2dXErwePPuwhYHpunMpfKIZxfNVdxcd|title=No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit's History |publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=4 June 2013}} On 8 August it moved to [[Kiriwina]], under the aegis of [[No. 73 Wing RAAF|No. 73 (Fighter) Wing]]. Steege relinquished command on 1 October to take charge of No. 73 Wing.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/people_8291.asp |title=Air Commodore Gordon Henry Steege|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate= 6 June 2013}} Responsible for controlling anti-aircraft batteries and air-to-air interceptions of Japanese raiders, the unit was renamed No. 114 (Mobile) Fighter Sector on 18 October. It registered its first "kill" on 31 October, when it directed a [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] of [[No. 79 Squadron RAAF|No. 79 Squadron]] to intercept a Japanese [[Kawasaki Ki-61|"Tony"]] fighter north-east of Kiriwina. On 2 March 1944, No. 114 Fighter Sector began redeploying with No. 73 Wing from Goodenough to [[Los Negros Island]]. Charged with coordinating air defence during the [[Admiralty Islands campaign]], it was renamed No. 114 Mobile Fighter Control Unit (MFCU) five days later.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/collection/records/awmohww2/air/vol2/awmohww2-air-vol2-ch11.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 173–176] The redesignated unit became operational on 2 April, and controlled Nos. 337, 340, 345, 346 and 347 Radar Stations. In January 1945, No. 114 MFCU was withdrawn to [[Brisbane]], where it began preparations to participate in the Australian-led [[Battle of Tarakan (1945)|liberation of Tarakan]]. In April, with a complement of over 800 officers and men, and Nos. 167, 168, 308, 354 and 355 Radar Stations under its command, it embarked for [[Morotai]] in the [[Dutch East Indies]]. From there it departed for Tarakan, arriving with the main invasion force on 1 May. Controlled by [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 (Fighter) Wing]] under the [[Australian First Tactical Air Force]] (No. 1 TAF), No. 114 MFCU became operational on the island four days after the landing. In addition to its regular duties, it temporarily took responsibility for maintaining contact with No. 1 TAF headquarters on Morotai and [[United States Army Air Forces|US Army Air Forces]] commands in the Philippines, when equipment belonging to the RAAF's Mobile Telecommunications Unit failed to be unloaded at Tarakan before the departure of its transport ship.Waters, ''Oboe'', p. 44 ===Cold War and after=== No. 114 MFCU was rapidly reduced in size following the end of the war. It departed Tarakan for Australia on 3 December 1945 with No. 78 Wing, arriving at [[Deniliquin Airport|RAAF Station Deniliquin]], New South Wales, on the 14th. Still under the wing's control, it relocated to [[RAAF Station Schofields]] on 31 May and then to [[RAAF Base Williamtown|RAAF Station Williamtown]] on 1 August, disbanding on 1 April 1948. No. 114 MFCU was re-established under a newly organised No. 78 Wing on 24 January 1949—"in name only", however, as it remained non-operational.No. 78 Wing Headquarters, "Operations Record Book", p. 160 It began training in late 1955 prior to anticipated reactivation, and was renamed No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit (MCRU) on 12 March 1956. It relocated to [[Dubbo|RAAF Dubbo]] and stood up as an independent unit on 14 November. [[File:RAAF radar.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.24|AN/TPS-77 radar of the type that currently equips No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit|alt=Radar unit on truck]] No. 114 MCRU deployed to [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] in 1958, becoming operational at [[RMAF Butterworth|RAAF Base Butterworth]] on 19 August. It took over responsibility for aerial surveillance and ground-controlled interception from the [[Royal Air Force]]'s No. 487 Signals Unit on 1 December. From Butterworth, No. 114 MCRU directed the [[CAC Sabre|Sabre]] fighters of [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 3]] and [[No. 77 Squadron RAAF|77 Squadrons]] and the [[English Electric Canberra|Canberra]] bombers of [[No. 2 Squadron RAAF|No. 2 Squadron]] in the last years of the [[Malayan Emergency]]. It also sent controllers on attachment to [[Ubon Royal Thai Air Force Base|Ubon Air Base]] in Thailand, where No. 79 Squadron was based from 1962.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 272–273 On 3 September 1964, the unit went on to a 24-hour operational footing to support the [[AIM-9 Sidewinder|Sidewinder-armed]] Sabres of Nos. 3 and 77 Squadrons during the [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|''Konfrontasi'']] between Indonesia and Malaysia, though no combat ensued.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 251–252 ''Konfrontasi'' having been declared over in August 1966, No. 114 MCRU transferred its responsibilities to RAF Western Hill on 22 September, and disbanded at Butterworth on 31 October. The unit was reactivated again at [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland, on 1 April 1968, employing the [[Plessey]] "Hub Cap" automated air defence system, which utilised [[Northrop Grumman|Westinghouse]] radar and [[Marconi]] computer programs.Stephens, ''Soing Solo'', pp. 353–354 It was to have moved directly from Butterworth to Amberley but delivery of the Hub Cap system, ordered in 1965, was delayed owing to programming issues. The system was also physically larger and heavier than had been anticipated, rendering it less easily transportable.Stephens, ''Soing Solo'', p. 393 In 1979, No. 114 MCRU upgraded to the Westinghouse [[AN/TPS-43]] radar system, improving both its mobility and its tactical capabilities. It inaugurated the RAAF's Tactical Air Defence System (TADS, subsequently Tactical Air Defence Radar System or TADRS) on 10 July 1985.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4712/topstories/story12.htm |title=Tactical radar tested|last= Lowe |first=Georgina|magazine=Air Force |volume=47 |issue=12|date=14 July 2005|accessdate=21 January 2014}} No. 114 MCRU was presented with a Squadron Standard on 23 May 1990, becoming the only non-flying unit in the Air Force to receive such an honour.{{cite magazine|url=http://digital.realviewtechnologies.com/default.aspx?xml=defencenews_airforce.xml|title=Big day for proud unit|magazine=Air Force |volume=55 |issue=9|page=7| date=6 June 2013|accessdate=6 June 2013}} The standard displays [[battle honour]]s for the Pacific (1943–45), New Britain (1943), New Guinea (1943–44) and Borneo (1945). No. 114 MCRU was transferred to [[RAAF Base Tindal]], Northern Territory, in May–June 1997, and then to [[RAAF Base Darwin]] in December 1999. The AN/TPS-43 was retired in September 2005, and replaced by the [[AN/FPS-117|AN/TPS-77]] radar.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4717/topstories/story04.htm |title=Radar's last hurrah|last= Johnson |first=Laura|author2=Maika, Jaimee |magazine=Air Force |volume=47 |issue=17|date=22 September 2005|accessdate=6 June 2013}} In May 2007, a detachment of 75 members of No. 114 MCRU deployed for active service at [[Kandahar Airfield]] in [[Operation Slipper|southern Afghanistan]], utilising the AN/TPS-77 to coordinate coalition combat air operations.{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/download/2007/may/20070531/ |title=No. 114 Mobile Control and Reporting Unit deploys to Afghanistan|publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]]|date=31 May 2007|accessdate=6 June 2013}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4918/international/story1.htm |title=Kylie's in control|last= Jamieson|first=Cameron|magazine=Air Force |volume=49 |issue=18|date=4 October 2007|accessdate=6 June 2013}} The detachment returned to Australia in August 2009. No. 114 MCRU celebrated its 70th anniversary at Darwin on 23 May 2013. It marked ten years service with the AN/TPS-77 radar in November 2015.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=6&iid=132788#folio=13 |title=Decade of reliable service|magazine=Air Force |volume=57 |issue=23|date=3 December 2015|page=13|accessdate=30 November 2015}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite journal|last=[[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 Wing Headquarters]]|title=Operations Record Book |url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=1360020|work=RAAF Unit History sheets (Form A50)|publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]]}} *{{cite book|last=Odgers | first=George |authorlink=George Odgers|origyear=1957| year=1968| title=Australia in the War of 1939–1945: Series Three (Air) Volume II – Air War Against Japan 1943–1945 | location=Canberra| publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1070210/|oclc=11218821}} *{{Cite book|author=RAAF Historical Section|year=1995|title=Units of the Royal Australian Air Force: A Concise History.
